content.description: Nice off-width crack with some extra features to help the off-width adverse climbers out there.  Short and finishes among a pile of loose rocks that should be avoided when continuing up to the rappel tree of Blue Bayou.
content.location: In the corner to the right of Blue Nun and left of Blue Bayou

climbs.name: Rhythm & Blues
climbs.fa: Todd Swain and Patty Furbush, April 1985

content.description: an excellent fingertip lieback on superb rock
content.location: This is a short route, starting well up and right from the other climbs on the formation.

climbs.name: Out of the Blue
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Frank Bentwood, and Al Sanderson

content.description:
This is a variation to Blues Brothers, with exceptionally good rock quality. The rock is extraordinarily smooth for Joshua Tree. Four out of five stars.

Start 20 feet left of Blues Brothers. Climb the slab past 4 bolts (10d/11a above the 2nd bolt), moving left at the fourth bolt to a thin seam that is followed up and right to where it joins Blues Brothers, then make a somewhat run-out face move (5.8 PG) up to a straight-in crack which leads to ledges. Move right and climb the headwall just right of the regular Blues Brothers finish, up to a fixed pin, from where you can continue straight up (10+) or move right to a ledge for an easier (5.9) finish.

2 bolt anchor (90 Ft.)

climbs.name: Once in a Blue Moon
climbs.fa: Patty Furbush and Todd Swain, April 1985

content.description: Start up a curving crack that quickly ends and continue up the low-angled featured face with minimal protection.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches including the belay
content.location:
Just left of

Blue Nun

on the far left side of the crag.

content.description: Starts with a shallow crack not easily protected, on beautiful, smooth rock. Hidden right facing hold on right crucial to keep it at 5.10a. Thats all the info you get!
content.protection: Small cams/nuts. Also there is a single bolt/no hanger that can be used via a wired nut. This route is not easily protected and moves from crack to unprotected face (short move). Build your own anchor and rap off a slung tree. 60m rope.

content.description: Ascends the face between Blues Brothers and Blue Monday.
content.location: Left formation of the Hill Street Blues area

climbs.name: Blue Nun
climbs.fa: Todd Swain and Patty Furbush, April 1985

content.description: This climb is very short, but with a few neat moves.  Protection is somewhat difficult to place
content.location: This is a zigzag crack near the left end of the formation.

climbs.name: Blue Monday
climbs.fa: Darrel Hensel, Alan Roberts and Dave Evans,

content.description: Blue Monday takes a thin wandering line up the right side of the Hill Street Blues crag.  Start up an easy slab to gain a flared notch with a very thin crack in the back.  Put in some tiny nuts and the smallest cam you have, then pull the insecure crux to gain better holds (hard for .10b).  Continue up wafer thin crispy flakes with easy climbing but poor pro to a stance.  A shallow corner with more small pro requires some more slabracadabra to gain a broken ledge and some straightforward crack climbing to the tree.  Belay.  Descent bolts atop Blues Brothers are 12 feet away.
content.protection: Gear to 2", tiny nuts and tiny cams.
content.location: First route you arrive at at the top of the trail.  About 20 feet right of the distinctive thin crack of Blues Brothers.

content.description: Top rope the slab just left of Blue Bayou, moving right to use the arete for a move or two about 20 feet up.

climbs.name: Blue Bayou
climbs.fa: Patty Furbush and Todd Swain, April 1985

content.description: The left-most route on this face, about 30 feet left of Blues Brothers. Start by the pine tree and go straight up the highly featured and large cam eating corner (I used 2 #1, a #2, & a #3). Not bad for a 5.4 a good route. Use if you are not comfortable with the sparse protection on Blues Brothers and would rather top rope it...
content.protection: Large up to 3" although you can get small gear in frequently. There is a decent crack system at the top and a bolted anchor.
content.location: Far left on the Hill Street Blues Right Formation.    The webbing rap anchors are looking pretty sketchy (as of 1-3-09)so it would be a wise idea to bring new slings as there isn't much in the way of natural protection at the top.
